newsitem.title: UK: UK Rifkind denies only Clarke blocks EMU rejection.
newsitem.headline: UK Rifkind denies only Clarke blocks EMU rejection.

text.p: UK Foreign Secretary Malcolm Rifkind denied suggestions that Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke was the only obstacle preventing the Conservative government from rejecting participation in a single currency.
"That is actually a misrepresentation," he told a BBC television interviewer on Wednesday who asked him if this was the case.
"Of course there is a difference of view within the Conservative Party. There is one in the Labour party as well."
Rifkind also said that Britain would not have to decide on whether to participate in monetary union until the end of 1997, not at the beginning of the year as some people had suggested.
"The earliest a single currency can happen is just about 2-1/2 years from now," he said.
"You would certainly have to take a decision by the end of 1997 if you wanted to join a single currency and if it was going to actually happen on January 1, 1999."

Rifkind said Britain' national interest would be the primary consideration. "It would be wrong to reach a premature decision on a single currency that cannot happen for more than two years -- and may not happen for many years after that."
